‘Alright, let’s go.’  
‘He will be very happy to meet you. I’ve talked about you to him many times. I was just talking about you yesterday. So you knew the old woman? That’s great! Oh, yes, Sofya Ivanovna…’  
‘Sofya Semyonovna,’ Raskolnikov corrected. ‘Sofya Semyonovna, this is my friend Razumihin, and he is a good man.’  
‘If you have to go now,’ Sonia started, not looking at Razumihin and feeling more awkward.  
‘Let’s go,’ Raskolnikov decided. ‘I will come to see you today, Sofya Semyonovna. Just tell me where you live.’  
He didn’t seem nervous, but he was in a hurry and avoided her gaze. Sonia gave her address and blushed. They all went outside together.  
‘Don’t you lock your door?’ Razumihin asked, following him down the stairs.  
‘Never,’ Raskolnikov replied. ‘I’ve been meaning to buy a lock for two years. People who don’t need locks are happy,’ he said, laughing at Sonia. They paused in the doorway.  
‘Do you go to the right, Sofya Semyonovna? By the way, how did you find me?’ he added, as if he wanted to say something else. He wanted to look into her soft, clear eyes, but it was hard.  
‘You gave your address to Polenka yesterday.’  
‘Polenka? Oh, yes; Polenka, the little girl. She is your sister? Did I give her my address?’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov and Sonia discuss their acquaintance and plans to meet, revealing a growing connection between them.
